title: Evan Chesler
description: Attorney Evan Chesler believes that "you can go a long way in America if you just work hard." The New York Public Library played an important role in Evan's own career trajectory. As a student at Junior High School 135 in the Northeast Bronx, he studied at the Allerton Branch with his friends. As a young man, he used the research facilities at the 42nd Street Main Library while writing a textbook on Joseph Stalin and Russian Jews.Today, Evan, a partner at a prestigious law firm, serves as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of The New York Public Library system. In this role, he oversees the operations of the entire library system and is helping it transition to the digital world. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Neighborhood Memory Circle - Trains, Theaters, and Parks (see Storyteller names below)
description: David Applebaum, Lois Fermaglich, Eugene Joyce, Joan Laddaga, Victor Mastrovincenzo, Tom Vasti

title: Gene DeFrancis
description: Gene De Francis, Director of the Allerton Avenue Merchants Association, remembers playing stoop ball, kick the can, curb ball, whiffle ball and a variety of other street games, as well as softball with the Pelham Parkway Little League. Those childhood games helped form the basis of friendships that have lasted a lifetime. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Neighborhood Food Memory Circle (See storyteller names below)
description: Robert Ciccone, Arnold Kaplan, Jacqueline Levy, Barry Michaels, Peter Ulrich, Meryl Shaye

title: Adele Acampora Pasmantier
description: Long-time Bronx resident Adele Acampora Pasmantier shares memories of her close-knit Italian family and their lives in the Morris Park area of the Bronx. From recollections of neighborhood Victory Gardens and food rationing during World War II to memories of happier times attending neighborhood schools, shopping at nearby Westchester Square or dancing at the Starlight Ballroom in West Farms, Adele recounts life in the mid-twentieth century. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Andrea Rizzi, Anita Perillo, and Rosemarie Terenzio
description: Andrea Rizzi, Anita Perillo, and Rosemarie Terenzio are from the Van Nest section of the Bronx. These three sisters share memories of shopping at neighborhood stores, enjoying egg creams at the local luncheonette, and sharing produce from backyard gardens with their neighbors. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Arlene Alda
description: When author Arlene Alda was growing up on Barnes Avenue in the 1930s and '40s, the neighborhood was her world. Arlene shares her memories of growing up in a working class Jewish family in the northeast Bronx and recalls the impact the Depression and World War II had on her family. From Saturday afternoons watching movies at the Allerton Theater, to quiet Sundays at the New York Botanical Gardens, to playing "Kings" outside The Mayflower, the 96-unit apartment building where her family lived, Arlene recreates a time when "everyone knew everyone else." (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Neighborhood Food Memory Circle (See storyteller names below)
description: David Appelbaum, Janka Cvorovic Esposito, Cecilia Haas, Francine Jackel, Joan Laddaga, Andrea Siegel, Salvatore Signoriello

title: Mark Gjonaj
description: State Assemblyman Mark Gjonaj briefly reminisces about growing up in the Bronx, moving from Arthur Avenue to Eastchester Road, near Pelham Parkway, the changes he has witnessed in the neighborhood, and the cultural diversity that makes the Bronx so special. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Al D'Angelo
description: Al D'Angelo has worked hard to build a successful neighborhood association. This retired teacher, a long-time resident of the Morris Park area of the Bronx, has been actively involved with community groups for over 40 years. While he's seen the neighborhood evolve in many ways, Al's efforts and the work of many other residents has kept the area safe for residents of all ages. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)
notes: Interviewed by Jeremy Warneke (Part 1) and Janka Cvorovic (Part 2)

title: Joanne Conte, Constantino Isabella, and Joan Mayer
Lois Gelber Fermaglich
description: Lois Gelber Fermaglich often returns to her old neighborhood in the Bronx. And she wonders why that borough hasn't yet experienced a renaissance, as Brooklyn has. Her experiences growing up near Pelham Parkway evoke only good memories. And she's sure that the Bronx can offer similar experiences again to an influx of new residents. Beautiful parks, close-knit neighbors and a wide selection of places where one can enjoy a variety of ethnic foods are all still there -- if only people would venture north of Manhattan. Lois brings to life the daily routines she so vividly remembers and shares her sense of wonder as she ventured beyond her neighborhood's boundaries -- to junior high school in Parkchester, to the west Bronx to attend Hunter College, to medical school in Kentucky. But always, her heart is in the Bronx, where the sound of an elevated subway evokes memories of waking each morning in her childhood home on Kruger Avenue. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Rose Hartman
description:
Rose Hartman is a Documentary Photographer who has been capturing stylish images for over 34 years. Rose was interviewed by Gemma Haywood on March 2nd 2014, the two had not met before this interview. Rose has been living in Greenwich Village since November 1963. 

Rose has lived through the major changes that have occurred in the village , these include commercialization and the extinction of individual enterprises. She describes this in her interview and also mentions the people responsible for this change and those who have suffered. 
Because of Rose's occupation she is acquainted with some of the most influential and famous people that Greenwich village has seen. She explains why the village attracts these people and their personalities.
Rose also tells how the village has acted as a sanctuary for her and shares some of her best memories in the West village.

title: Janet Glazer
description: The East Village in the 1950s was a nearly ideal place for a creative child like Janet Glazer to grow up. Her parents were caught up in socialist political movements but were also members of The People’s Chorus. Janet’s mother, Dora Ross Glazer, was an energetic organizer of local music and dance performances and the neighborhood was home to many theaters. Janet has been painting since she can remember and later became a photographer. She has contributed to historic preservation since the 1980s by photographing details of old buildings all over the city.

title: Myra Nissim
description: Myra Nissim is a shy woman who spent her life working to better the lives of others. Her interests include photography, ceramics, religion, child psychology, and truck driving. In the 1980s acquaintances introduced Myra to someone who had been a great inspiration to her; Greenwich Village resident and street photographer Helen Levitt. The two remained friends for over 20 years. Myra has exhibited her own photographs in a number of local galleries and she shares reminisces of favorite shops and cafés. (Summary Written By: Myra Nissim)

title: Chris Kapp
description: Chris Kapp discusses her early life in living Greenwich. She touchs on subjects such as the development of the gay rights movement, the culture of the village in the 70s, and her interactions with celebrities. (Summary Written By: Lucy Doherty)

title: Lisa Davis
description: In the 1940s Mafia-owned nightclubs featuring gay floorshows were very popular in Greenwich Village. They were also illegal. A generation later young Lisa Davis met a number of retired performers who had fond memories of their show business careers and Lisa wrote her first novel “Under the Mink” about this world. Lisa also discusses anti-Communism and local residents Angela Calomiris (an FBI informant) and actress Judy Holliday. A Village resident since 1974, Lisa recalls her favorite haunts and how her neighbors, the neighborhood and the world have changed. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Barbara Sherman
description:
Barbara Sherman arrived in the Big Apple after nursing school and worked at NYU Medical Center. She's lived in Greenwich Village since 1958 but moved 10 times before settling in an apartment on lower Fifth Avenue. Barbara adjusted easily to the neighborhood and her stories run the gamut from exotic pets to the local hangout for car racing enthusiasts to drug dealers who ruled a nearby street corner. She remembers many popular bars and restaurants and recalls the tragic day of 9/11. (Summary Written By: Georgina Johnston)

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; Christopher Street; nightlife; small business. 

Additional key words: Sports Car Club of America; 540 Hudson Street; bartenders; white-brick buildings; hospital closings.

title: Martha Taylor Butler
notes: Interviewed by Emily Jacobson and Louise Stamp

title: Michael Urgo
description: Michael Urgo was born and raised on Sullivan Street in Greenwich Village. In 1960 at the age of 16 Michael set up a club named The Château Club with his friends. This bar ran under their ownership for 15 years and during this time Michael saw his fair share of eventful nights as they hosted the different characters of Greenwich Village. After the club was sold Michael was the owner of many other enterprises in Greenwich Village often getting his whole family involved. This interview was conducted by Marilyn Astarita Stevenson on April 2nd 2014 in Albany. During his interview Michael tells his fascinating story about growing up in Greenwich Village, his neighbors and making money in the most inventive ways.

title: Nicola Perry
description: At the age of 21, Nicola Perry immigrated from England to New York City to open Tea & Sympathy. Nikki contrasts the relatively easy feat of acquiring a commercial space in The Village then v.s. now, the trickle down effect that real estate greed has had on the economy, and the struggle of raising a child in a city ran by the bourgeoisie. (Summary Written By: Halle Roberts)

title: Addis Williams
description: Addis Williams, who began working in show business at age seven or eight, discusses his long career as a puppeteer. In addition to appearing in New York nightclubs, he travelled around the world, performing in many languages, including French, Spanish and Japanese. Over the length of his career, Addis built over 5,000 puppets used in film, theater and television. He moved to Greenwich Village in 1957 and remembers an early Halloween Parade in which he performed as a seven-foot tall witch. (Summary Written By: Georgina Johnston)

title: Johnny Green
description: Johnny Green came to Greenwich Village in the late 1960s. After growing up in a small town in Southwest Texas he moved to Atlanta and eventually joined the local production of 'Stomp', a rock musical that was also a hippie commune. The Public Theater brought 'Stomp' to New York where the cast and crew lived and performed in Martinson Hall. Within a year Johnny found an apartment in the West Village where he has lived ever since. He worked in sales at an upscale sex boutique and for nearly 20 years has been house manager at The Actors Studio. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Penny Blum
description: Penny Blum has lived on Washington Square Park since the mid-1930s. Her social life centered on the coffee houses and bars along MacDougal Street. Penny remembers a time when there were many townhouses and no high-rise buildings in the neighborhood but NYU has taken over Greenwich Village, buying and demolishing properties for new construction. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Jim Fouratt
description: Jim Fouratt arrived in New York City in 1960. He attended classes at the Actors Studio taught by Lee Strasberg with fellow students Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand. Jim shares his views on the acting profession past and present. He recalls iconic people, places and events from the Greenwich Village art world to the West Coast. Both a participant in and chronicler of political and cultural movements, Jim discusses anti-war demonstrations, feminism, and gay rights. Finally, he offers several reasons why the underground lifestyle he once knew so well has disappeared. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Jason Rogan
description: When he was two years old, Jason Rogan’s family moved to Washington Place and Jason and his sister attended local public schools. Jason talks about the mid-1980s crack epidemic that destroyed the area’s relaxed atmosphere. Although the neighborhood recovered, he feels it has become much more touristy and there are fewer places to buy everyday things. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Carolyn Dickie
description: Carolyn Dickie graduated from nursing school in 1976 and worked at St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village for 35 years. She still resides in the neighborhood and shares stories of working in the hospital's emergency room, riding in the ambulance with the medics, providing primary medical care to the homeless, and unwinding with her co-workers at local hangouts. She is sad to see that so many local small businesses have disappeared since St. Vincent’s closed. Finally, Carolyn recalls the tragic day of September 11, 2001. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: John Joseph Stanley
description: John Joseph Stanley walked downtown to Greenwich Village in 1954 and got a job as dishwasher at La Palette restaurant on Bleecker Street. He soon learned of a vacant apartment on Christopher Street where he has lived ever since. John talks about becoming an actor, working at NYU’s student financial aid office, and visiting Cuba in 1968. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Arthur Stoliar
description:
Arthur Stoliar moved from Brooklyn to Greenwich Village in 1953, where he still lives. Activist Jane Jacobs was a great influence and he became a community leader opposed to plans of developers such as Robert Moses. Arthur was appointed member of the Community Board and as chairman of two committees he received constant applications to change old streets and build new roads through the Village. Many of these proposals were unpopular and were defeated, sometimes after long legal battles. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; politicians; real estate development; social conditions. 
Additional key words: West Side Highway; Westway.

title: Jeanne Youngson
description: When Jeanne Youngson came to New York in 1951 she was drawn to the small town atmosphere of Greenwich Village and met many artists at the bars and restaurants where they gathered. After her marriage she moved into a penthouse on Washington Square West where she has lived for 55 years.(Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Lucienne Weinberger
description: Lucienne Weinberger and her husband were among the first people to move into Westbeth Artists’ Housing in 1970 and considered themselves urban pioneers in an area consisting of vacant warehouses, an abandoned elevated highway and rotting piers. The waterfront began changing in the mid 1980s when old buildings were converted into residential lofts and the West Side Highway was dismantled and replaced by Hudson River Park. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Sheila Short
description:
Sheila Short has lived in the same walk-up building on West 10th Street since 1958. She is interviewed by a friend. 

When she moved in nearly everyone in Greenwich Village was gay including her landlords. Eventually they offered her an apartment on a lower floor at no increase in rent. Many of her neighbors died of AIDS and she is the only elderly person in the building. 

Sheila worked for TWA and has visited many countries. She has been employed at a travel agency uptown for 50 years. 

The neighborhood once was quite industrial and shopping was difficult but Sheila always felt safe. She knows all the local restaurants and goes out every night. St. Veronica’s Church is nearby but no longer has its own pastor. 

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; nightlife; social life & customs. 
Additional key words: Weehauken Street; D’Agostino; Peter Rabbit.

title: Doris Diether
description: When Doris Diether arrived in Greenwich Village in 1950 she lived in a series of hotels and rooming houses. Almost from the beginning she sought out political leaders to discuss problems such as tenants rights and eventually joined activists Jane Jacobs and Shirley Hayes as co-founder of Save The Village. Using a strategy that focused on re-zoning and landmarking plus a flair for publicity, the organization succeeded in preserving large areas of the neighborhood. In the 1960s Doris was appointed to Manhattan’s Community Board 2 and she has continued her public service through many mayoral administrations to the present. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Angelo Verga
description: Angelo Verga is a poet and a professor. Although a Bronx native and long-time resident of that borough, he was attracted to Greenwich Village and made frequent visits from the time he was a teenager. During the 1990s, Angelo became a significant member of the poetry circuit, performing his work at such famous places as the Nuyorican Poet’s Café and the Cornelia Street Café. Among his friends are active poets and Greenwich Village residents Douglas Goetsch and Sanford Fraser. (Summary Written By: Georgina Johnston)

title: Frank Saponara
description: Frank Saponara’s grandparents came from Italy and settled in Greenwich Village where he remembers growing up in a close-knit neighborhood. As a teenager his family moved to a new apartment several blocks south of Little Italy and Frank started working as a busboy at a famous midtown restaurant. At home his mother Gaetana taught him how to cook his favorite Sicilian dishes. Thirty years later Frank’s life has come full circle as he owns and operates a restaurant -- dedicated to his parents -- on Christopher Street in his old neighborhood. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Charles Mirisola, Sr.
description: In 1949, Charles Mirisola and his wife opened up a clothing store named Etcetera on West 4th Street. With the help of relatives they added stores, started a local garment factory and developed a thriving wholesale business. After living in several apartments in the neighborhood Charles bought the house where he still lives. He remembers the Village as a safe, easy-going place to raise his five children and today considers Greenwich Village the best retirement community in the world. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Alison Armstrong
description:
Alison Armstrong was born in Ohio. She lived in Europe for a few years during her studies. She is a professor at the School of Visual Arts, a writer and a painter. She is the author of "The Joyce of Cooking".
After visiting a cousin, she decided to establish herself in New York City. She went to NYU and applied to the Westbeth Artists Housing project. She started teaching for various universities. 
Alison lived in many New York neighborhoods before moving to Greenwich Village. She was active with the Federation to Preserve the Greenwich Village Waterfront and Great Port in 1993. She talks about the many changes that occurred there. It went from being a dangerous neighborhood to a creative hub when wealthy young people moved in during the 1980's. Since then, the neighborhood has held onto its sense of community and history.

title: Mentina Christopher
description: Mentina Christopher was 11 years old in 1942 when her family moved to a small apartment on 6th Avenue. While Mentina attended local schools and explored different neighborhoods, her parents adjusted to the American way of life and preserved their Northern Italian traditions. Although she left the area when she got married, Mentina has always cherished her memories of growing up in Greenwich Village. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Elaine Mobray
description: Elaine Mobray's family emigrated to Greenwich Village from Italy at the turn of the twentieth century. For Elaine, the area has always been 'the neighborhood.' She remembers a childhood full of lively activities and interesting characters. She watched as the Village's warehouse-filled streets transformed into hangouts for hippies, tourists, writers, and runaways. There were family owned businesses to shop in and famous faces to glimpse on the street. Elaine decided to attend New York University because she believed that nowhere in the world could be as great as Lower Manhattan. Today, she continues to work in publishing and remembers her youth in Greenwich Village fondly, while recognizing the many ways the neighborhood has changed. (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Norman Kahn
description: After living in a number of apartments in the Village, in 1977 Norman Kahn and his wife used their life savings to buy one of seven brownstones for sale on West 11th Street. Norman discusses the history of his block which includes St. John’s in the Village church and one of the few private gardens in New York City. He also describes favorite restaurants and businesses and people he meets in his neighborhood. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Leslie Taylor
description: Leslie Taylor was born in Berlin, Germany. In 1942, she moved to New York City, one of many refugees escaping the turmoil of World War II. After becoming a citizen, Leslie moved to Greenwich Village and has lived there for more than 45 years. Leslie discusses such issues such as citizenship, discrimination, segregation and the U.S. gun laws and offers her unique perspective on how she sees the world. (Summary Written By: Georgina Johnston)

title: Robert E. Rambusch
description:
Robert Rambusch has lived in Greenwich Village since 1945. He is interviewed by a friend. 

Robert is a veteran of World War II and before his marriage lived in his parent’s home at 19 Washington Square North while working as an artist in the family business on West 13th Street. 

As a student Robert had been a delegate to political conferences around the world. 
His wife Nancy was an educator and the couple was swept into the political fervor of the 1960s. 

After living in a number of apartments in the Village, Robert bought his father’s condo at One Fifth Avenue where he still works as a consultant on stained glass windows and mosaics. 

Greenwich Village is a haven for creative people and the only place to live if you want to stay young. 

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; church buildings; real estate development; schools; social conditions. 
Additional key words: Montessori; NYU; St. Joseph’s church; senior citizens.

title: John Noble Wilford
description: John Noble Wilford is an accomplished journalist who spent 45 years at The New York Times. In 1970, he and his wife bought a small house on West 10th Street that was originally built in 1833 when Greenwich Village was a rural area. John has researched the history of his house and, through recollections of people, streets, popular places and events from the 1800s through Hurricane Sandy, he reveals aspects of a changing neighborhood. (Summary Written By: Georgina Johnston)

title: LindaAnn Loschiavo
description: LindaAnn Loschiavo moved to Greenwich Village as a teenager when criminal activity permeated the neighborhood. Rather than being discouraged she turned to bodybuilding for self-defense. An avid interest in both local and women’s history inspired LindaAnn to write a play ‘Courting Mae West’ which is based on a famous 1928 incident in which the Broadway star was arrested, taken to the Women’s House of Detention, and prosecuted on morals charges at Jefferson Courthouse (now Jefferson Market Library). LindaAnn says traces of the old Village can still be found today. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Ralph Lee
notes: Interviewed by Halina Warren / Alexandra Kelly

title: Gloria McDarrah
description: Gloria McDarrah has lived in the Village since the 1950s. Before her husband Fred McDarrah established himself as a photojournalist, he worked as a doorman at the Artists’ Club. Gloria notes that although many small businesses have disappeared Greenwich Village is still a wonderful place to live. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Chris Billias
description: Chris Billias comes from a musical family in Brooklyn and as a teenager he chose to attend public school in Manhattan. At that age he spent a lot of time around Greenwich Village bars and clubs where he was too young to be admitted but could still hear the live music from his spot outside on the sidewalk. His first job was working as a figure model at New York art schools and he posed for many individual artists as well. Chris traveled often pursuing interests in writing, music and Kalmyk Buddhism but he always returned to New York’s downtown neighborhoods and still lives in the East Village. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Peter Lewy
description:
Peter Lewy is a cellist / composer who has performed on the streets in Greenwich Village since the 1990s. 

Peter began his career in upstate New York as singer / songwriter / guitarist with a folk rock band. Hoping to make a living as a street musician, he studied classical music to improve his skills on the cello. 

He worked as a piano tuner when he first arrived in New York City. During that time his band played at Folk City and other clubs. Peter opened for Jaco Pastorius at The Blue Note. The Village is a very good place for street performers due to the influx of tourism. 

Peter visited Italy 20 years ago to see what playing there was like. He spends 8 weeks every summer in Tuscany and the Lakes region. 

Additional controlled search terms: musicians; nightlife; parks; September 11 Terrorist Attacks, 2001; Washington Square. 
Additional key words: 9/11; Washington Square fountain; The High Line.

title: Charles Cosentino
description: Charles Cosentino lives across the river in Jersey City. For about 15 years starting in 1982 he spent a lot of time in The Village. Uncle Charlie’s Downtown on Greenwich Avenue was the first gay bar Charles went into and he became a cocktail waiter and occasional DJ there. It was a popular high-end venue but one of the first terrorist attacks and a murder scandal were also part of its history. Charles has always walked around the neighborhood taking pictures and maintains a popular Facebook page. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Diana Schulman
description: When Diana Schulman moved to New York City she wanted to live in Greenwich Village because it reminded her of Paris. She has lived on West 10th Street since 1966, where landmarking has prevented high-rise construction. Diana remembers when her neighbors began buying second homes and no longer spent weekends walking around the Village, browsing the yard sales and artsy stores, going to restaurants and movies. Now, she says, the Village seems less homey and is more for students and tourists. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Rose Marie Galgano O'Leary
description:
Rose Marie Galgano O’Leary has lived at 30 Charlton Street for most of her life. She knows the interviewer from the library. 

Her maternal grandparents came to America from Basilicata province in southern Italy and settled in Greenwich Village in 1893. As more Italian immigrants moved in they took over Sullivan and Thompson Streets where blacks had lived since the Civil War. 

The Village became 2 distinct areas, Irish and Italian, each with their own church. Rose Marie tells several stories about her relatives. She also remembers going to school during the Great Depression and describes small businesses that have vanished from the neighborhood. 

More recently Rose Marie serves as board member of her block association and is responsible for turning an unseemly outdoor space into a community garden. 

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; church buildings; ethnic relations; McDougal Street; parks; politicians; restaurants; social conditions; social life and customs. 

Additional key words: 6th Avenue; Greenwich House; Washington Irving High School; New York Public Library (NYPL); Community Board.

title: Ellen Stevenson
description: Ellen Stevenson has been a Greenwich Village resident her entire married life. She describes the work of the Morton Street Block Association. In 1978 developers converted an old factory into residential lofts and Ellen and her husband were the first to buy an apartment. They waited 2 years for the renovations to be completed before moving in and have lived there for 34 years. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Susanna Aaron
description:
Susanna Aaron’s father moved to Greenwich Village before she was born in search of a more iconoclastic life. They both still reside in the neighborhood. 

Growing up Susanna remembers the area was very safe and she walked to school. In 1973 she was a member of the first graduating class of Village Community School.
Small businesses along Bleecker Street served the people who lived nearby, many of them Italian and Irish. Gradually Bleecker Street became known for its antique stores. 

Most townhouses were divided into apartments and most residents were not wealthy. 

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; schools; ethnic relations; St. Vincent’s Hospital. 

Additional key words: Bank Street School; inter-racial couple; single mothers.

title: Diane Martella
description: Diane Martella moved to New York from California and, through a friend, she found a room in the building where she still lives today. With another tenant, Diane rented the basement, and they turned it into a place where they showed plays written by people from the neighborhood. Thanks to word of mouth these evenings became increasingly popular with local residents. They enjoyed themselves; some even had interesting opportunities in show business. Diane also recalls all the neighborhood restaurants near her place on Hudson Street. (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Carol Kroker
description: Carol Kroker came to Greenwich Village in 1967 after graduating from college and found her first apartment by looking in The Village Voice. Carol describes 1970s culture and nightlife as diverse and affordable. Her present office is located in the former St. Denis Hotel which was built in the 1800’s. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Frances Hirschorn
description: In 1967, Frances Hirschorn moved into a Greenwich Village studio apartment where she has lived ever since. Although she worked in midtown Frances enjoyed going home to a neighborhood full of old streets and historic buildings. She remembers the Village as a casual place with lots of small businesses and excellent transportation. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Hara Seltzer
description: Hara Seltzer grew up in Brooklyn and is a visual artist. In 1977, she moved to a walk-up apartment on the corner of 7th Avenue South & Bleecker Street and stayed there for 35 years. She met unconventional people in Greenwich Village where the low rents allowed them to work fewer days and have more time to follow other interests. There were many small bars and restaurants where Hara used to hang out.(Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Susan Turok
description:
Susan Turok is a retired teacher and has lived in Greenwich Village off and on since 1964. She is interviewed by a long-time friend. 

Susan first moved to the area after college and she describes sharing a studio apartment in the Washington Square Village apartment complex. She then moved to a building near Christopher Street where friends helped her fix up an old run-down apartment. 

Susan enjoyed an active social life and describes favorite cafes, restaurants and specialty food stores. Many have disappeared but a few remain. 

After her marriage Susan and her husband moved uptown but returned to the Village 20 years ago. Since the 1990s real estate development has been very fast and the neighborhood is more crowded. 

Additional controlled search terms: buildings; MacDougal Street; NY Women’s House of Detention; small business. 
Additional key words: William B. White; Sutter’s bakery; coffee houses; Joe Jr’s diner; 6th Avenue.

title: Vivian Martinez
description:
Vivian Martinez and her husband have lived in Greenwich Village since the 1970s. She is interviewed by a neighbor. 

Vivian worked for Oliver Williams who owned properties in the neighborhood. She is the building superintendent at 55 Morton Street. In the 1920s Mr. Williams combined three 19th century buildings on the site into one apartment complex. In years since, period details from the renovation have been preserved including interior arches, high ceilings and brass ornamental fixtures. 

Mr. Williams was very involved in all aspects of his buildings and visited daily. As a landlord he took great care of his tenants and was also a good employer. The building was sold in the 1990s and since then rents are 15 times higher. 

Additional controlled search terms: social conditions.

title: Betsy Naylor
description: Betsy Naylor moved to New York City for graduate school and has lived in the same Greenwich Village apartment since 1968. She was a long-time political activist and talks about local Democratic clubs, candidates and neighborhood issues. Betsy is grateful for the opportunity to communicate her sense of history as she shares memories of vanished theaters, bookstores and larger institutions such as St. Vincent’s Hospital. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Cynthia Crane
description: Cynthia Crane is a singer/songwriter/producer/activist from a third generation New York family. In 1968 Cynthia and her husband bought a brownstone on West 11th Street where they lived for over 40 years. Cynthia talks about organizing a neighborhood association and holding block parties. Greenwich Village was the first neighborhood in the city to be landmarked but the battles over real estate development have never stopped. (Summary Written By: Elizabeth Downs)

title: Charlsie Wyche Bodie
description: Charlsie Wyche Bodie, a model and singer, moved to New York from Florida, where she had many opportunities to get involved in the Harlem's cultural and night life. One of her favorite haunts was the Apollo Theater, where she heard many great singers and also participated in Amateur Night. Charlsie went back to college several times to further her education and find new opportunities to have a good life. In this interview, she recalls a time when the people of Harlem, especially young people, had stronger values and when police discrimination seemed less prevalent. (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Aisha al-Adawiya
description: Aisha al-Adawiya, a Harlem resident for 35 years, also works  in Harlem - at the renowned Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

title: Nathalie Knobloch and Daniel Martinez
description: Nathalie Knobloch and Daniel Martinez share their experiences living in Harlem with their neighbor Sylvie Kande.

title: Inez Dickens - Interview II w/Anisha Huffman
Dame Babu
description: Journalist Dame Babu, a native of Senegal, describes his 27+ years living in Harlem.

title: Christopher Paul Moore
description: Mr. Moore works at the Schomberg Center for Research in Black Culture.

title: Bill Saxton
description: Bill Saxton, musician and owner of Bill's Place, a Harlem nightclub, has lived in Harlem since his birth.

title: Esmay Robinson
description: Esmay Robinson, a New York native, describes the changes she has seen during her 70 years as a Harlem resident.

title: Diane Boddie
description: Storyteller Diane Boddie describes the changes she's seen during her more than half a century living in West Harlem.

title: Wilhemina Enoch
description: Eighty-six year old Wilhemina Enoch, a retired New York City employee, shares her experiences living in Harlem with her daughter and interviewer Denise Davis-Maye.

title: Selena Freeman-Dixon
description: Selena Freeman-Dixon, a pharmacy & technology service clerk who has lived in Harlem since 1966, offers her unique perspective on the changes she has witnessed over the past 40+ years.

title: Jeanne Nedd
description: Jeanne Nedd has lived in Harlem for more than 16 sixteen years, many of them on 116th Street. Jeanne is very involved in the community and remembers when 116th street was known for illegal activities. Over the years, the neighborhood has changed, and now low-priced houses sit next to million dollar co-ops. Today, the neighborhood is more culturally and racially diverse, and there is a fairly large gay community. As for Jeanne, she appreciates everything the neighborhood has to offer -- especially the parks, the museums and the people. (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Esther Zhang
description: China-born Esther Zhang, a graduate student now residing in Harlem, shares her impressions of the neighborhood.

title: Michael Grattan
description: Michael Grattan, Pastor of Manhattan Pentecostal Church since 2005, shares his views on Harlem with interviewer Iris Grattan, his daughter.

title: Wardena Morrison
description: Ninety-six year old storyteller Wardena Morrison has lived in Harlem since 1940.

title: Rashida Ismaili
description: Professor of African Literature Ismaili Abu-Bakr Rashida gives her perspective on life in Harlem and the changes taking place in the area.

title: David House
description: David House has lived in New York for more than 15 years. He recalls life in Harlem from World War II to the present. Many events shaped the neighborhood. He and his father owned a famous barber shop, House's, that was frequented by many prominent personalities living in Harlem. He talks about some of his favorite neighborhood haunts. To him, Harlem remains a wonderful neighborhood, populated by really interesting and welcoming people. (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Ulysses Roundtree
description: Storyteller Ulysses Roundtree shares his Harlem experiences with his nephew and interviewer Charles Gale.

title: Allan and Pat Harris
description: Allan Harris has been living in Harlem since the 1950s. He remembers when the area was a safe haven for black people during segregation. The neighborhood was also a cultural hub that enriched him as a kid. During the Harlem Renaissance, artists, writers, and musicians gave Harlem its identity and its reputation. However, in the 1970s, the neighborhood was infested with drugs, and Harlem was considered dangerous. Then Harlem rose from its ashes again. Pat Harris remembers how welcoming people in Harlem were when she moved there. Despite the current gentrification, Harlem remains a special neighborhood and is still “a melting pot.” (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Douglas Payne
description: Douglas Payne is a retired musician from Harlem. He shares his deep insight and passion for the local music culture as he lived it. Dougie is a prodigiously talented multi-instrumentalist and virtuoso and has been involved in music for most of his life. During the 1980s, following his military service, he was at the heart of the funk and hip hop scenes, where he worked with such seminal figures as Rick James, Melle Mel and Frankie Crocker. His struggles with racism, poverty, and disability deeply color his experience. His musical success was regularly punctuated by homelessness and his struggles to receive his due benefits as a veteran. Outside of his work in music, Dougie is also deeply involved in Harlem at a wider community level as a teacher and, politically, through organizations like the Congress of Racial Equality (C.O.R.E.) and through the influence of such figures as Congressman Charlie Rangel. Dougie relates his music to the wider social issues of his experience, such as education, violence and aging. (Summary Written By: Danielle H. Lightfoot)

title: Cathy Bristow
description: Cathy Bristow initially moved to Harlem to move into a safehouse, in order to escape an abusive relationship. She eventually moved into an apartment in the neighborhood (where she still lives) and recalls spending much of her time there in her first few years looking for places where she felt safe, such as neighborhood restaurants, and parts of Central Park nearest to the obvious undercover cops. Alongside a very successful corporate career, Cathy has dedicated much of her life to trying to make Harlem, and the City as a whole, a better, safer, and more welcoming place for all kinds of people. In the interview, she discusses, among other things, mentoring people from the local Y, leading meetings in her home to talk about race, and throwing an engagement party for a gay couple with unsupportive parents. (Summary Written By: Henry Hauser)

title: Robert Graham
description: At 80 years of age, retired baker Robert Graham still rides his bike through Harlem. A long-time resident of the area, he shares his unique perspective on the changes he has witnessed during his more than 60 years living there.

title: Richard Granady
description: After more than 80 years as a Harlem resident, Richard Granady has a unique perspective on the evolution of the neighborhood.

title: Charles Rangel
description: Democratic Congressman Charles Rangel is a long-time member of the U.S. House of Representatives, serving the people of Harlem.

title: Abdou Karim Samb
description: Abdou Karim Samb arrived in New York in 1991 and moved to Harlem, where he felt very much at home. There was an important African community in Harlem, and he quickly adapted to life in Harlem. Abdou bought a taxi business with some Senegalese friends. He goes to the various mosques and enjoys eating at the numerous Senegalese an Ghanaian restaurants in the area. Mr. Samb also talks about the numerous changes taking place as rents increase; the neighborhood is now being populated by Europeans while many Africans are moving out. (Summary Written By: Nadia Bongo)

title: Alison Williams
description: Librarian Alison Williams describes the influence libraries and librarians have had in her life. From her days as a young truant seeking shelter in a Harlem branch library to her first job at the Mid-Manhattan branch of the New York Public Library, libraries have been a focal point for her. There, as a young girl, she discovered such writers as Ralph Ellison and Toni Morrison. Today, as manager of the Macombs Branch, she is now introducing these writers to young readers interested in "urban literature." As she moved around New York, Alison found herself always returning to Harlem to live or work, and she describes the impact gentrification is having on the area. (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Beau McCall
description: Growing up in South Philadelphia, Beau McCall dreamed of one day living in New York. A jazz music fan, when he finally moved to the city as a young man in the 1980s, his choice of neighborhood was clear: Harlem. In this interview, Beau shares many stories from his time in Harlem, touching on such topics as making a living for himself, experiencing Harlem's rich fashion and theater scenes, navigating relationships with drug-addicted neighbors and friends and practicing his art of button design. (Summary Written By: Henry Hauser)

title: William Seraile
notes: Interviewed by Sharon Mason (Part I) and Rose Merola (Part II)

title: Roger Parris
description: Retired social worker Roger Parris brings a lifetime of experiences in Harlem to his work as a playwright.

title: Beryl Epton
description: Teacher Beryl Epton has witnessed many changes in Harlem during the 84 years she has lived in the area.

title: Aden Seraile
description: Aden Seraile was born in Harlem where he lives now. He recalls the neighborhood's bad reputation, especially during the 1980s when Harlem was known to have a high crime rate and it was a dangerous area to walk around. Gradually, Harlem has become safer, and Aiden appreciates the fact that he lives in a historical neighborhood with beautiful buildings. Over time, Harlem has welcomed many famous artists and various communities, especially the black community. But now, as rents are getting higher, Harlem is changing once again. (Summary Written By: Nadia Bongo)

title: Christel Ellis
description: Librarian Christal Ellis recalls, in vivid detail, the Harlem of her youth. From the Mom & Pop stores of the 1970s and '80s, to today's chain stores, Christal compares Harlem as it once was to what it is in 2015. Eating chicken and waffles at Copeland's, buying ice cream from Mr. Softee, having her hair done at Rose Morgan's beauty parlor, seeing movies at the Victoria Movie Theater, and buying baked goods from Make My Cake -- all come to life as she reminisces. All was not perfect, however, as she also remembers the "crack era" and its negative impact on her neighborhood, as well as incidents of police brutality. Christal is optimistic about Harlem's future and hopes that, as it undergoes its resurgence, it can also "hold on to the essence of what Harlem was." (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Frank Morales
description: Frank Morales is a priest and long-time community organizer from the Lower East Side. In the early 1980s, Frank became involved with the workers' center Harlem Fight Back, at 125th Street, where he met Jim Haughton. He and Mr. Haughton organized the community around housing issues through the Harlem Reclamation Project, which fought to combat the displacement of poor communities of color through direct action. The displacement of poor communities was a widespread activity and part of what city housing officials called the "planned shrinkage" of the Harllem neighborhood. Frank returned to Harlem to serve at All Souls Episcopal Church on 114th Street, which he says strives to "bridge" new and old communities in south Harlem in solidarity. He reflects on his experience in the throes of change in Harlem over the decades. (Summary Written By: Danielle H. Lightfoot)

title: Lloyd Williams
description: Lloyd Williams, President of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, shares his knowledge of Harlem and the changes it is undergoing.

title: Aubrey Lynch
description: Aubrey Lynch, founder and director of Aubrey Lynch Extra Essential Arts, works in Harlem. Mr. Lynch was a former associate producer of the hit Broadway show "The Lion King" and is a former  dancer with the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater.

title: Dawn Celestine
description: Dawn Celestine, a lifelong resident of Harlem, discusses her upbringing in the 1960s and '70s. She paints a vivid picture of rich ties and associations in the community surrounding around 137th Street and her childhood home. Dawn's fond recollection of this community centers around the influence of her mother and her grandparents and the influence of their strong West Indian roots. This is a very personal account of the dynamic social currents gripping Harlem in the 1960s and beyond. (Summary Written By: Danielle H. Lightfoot)

title: Alvin Reed
description: Alvin Reed, owner of the famous Jazz club, the Lenox Lounge, recalls his excitement on arriving in Harlem and his eagerness to do something for the community. There were many opportunities in Harlem for black people escaping segregation in other states or neighborhoods. Alvin also remembers the famous artists who played in his Club, as well as many other individuals, such as the ganster Bumpy Johnson, who were a big part of the neighborhood. Alvin came from a poor background so he credits both hard work and walking the streets of Harlem as his sources of education. He now owns the Lenox Lounge, as well as several properties. As a true lover of Harlem, Alvin talks about the jazz clubs and all the various haunts that made Harlem such a rich neighborhood. (Summary Written By: Anonymous)

title: Myra King Hutchinson
description: Storyteller Myra King Hutchinson, a retired New York City public school teacher, shares her experiences living in Harlem with interviewer Valerie Smith, her friend for over 40 years.

title: October 8th Memory Circle at Inwood Library
December 12th Memory Circle
notes: Interviewed by Joanna Castro and Adriana Blancarte-Hayward

title: Robert Seidman
description: **Please Note: This interview is incomplete and will be completed within the duration of the SoHo Stories project.

title: Kevin Sullivan and Ingred Von Saltza
Diane Griffiths
notes: Interviewed by Richard Spiegel and Barbara Fisher

title: Grace Ambelas and William Hinton
description: Grace Ambelas and William Hinton describe their childhood in Staten Island starting in the 1950s. They recall a safe and welcoming neighborhood where different people cohabited. There was a sense of trust and solidarity among neighbors. Back then, kids would be sent to buy small items in shops and there they would do small jobs to earn some money for sweets. Therefore, the small businesses were some of their favorite haunts. They also recall their favorite improvised playgrounds around the neighborhood. Finally, the library was an important landmark for Grace and she describes her experience there. (Summary Written By: Nadia Bongo)

title: Octavio Felicie
description: The Inwood to which Octavio Felicie moved in 1968 was very different from the Inwood of today. He recalls facing discrimination and racial confrontations in the then mostly Irish neighborhood. Inwood’s Hispanic population grew rapidly during Octavio’s early days there, and this growth was accompanied by an increasing number of Hispanic nightclubs featuring such performers as Tito Puente and Ray Barretto. Octavio laments what he saw as a rise in drug-usage and crime in Inwood, but he also believes this has dropped since the 1990s. Despite all the change, Octavio maintains that he has always felt more at home in Inwood than in his native Puerto Rico. (Summary Written By: Henry Hauser)

title: Miriam Mejia
description: Since her childhood in the Dominican Republic, Miriam Mejia hasbeen interested in social justice. Her relentless political activism during her college years earned her a reputation as a "hot head." Even after moving to the United States with two small children, her commitment to social justice continued. Today, she is associated with numerous causes in her Washington Heights neighborhood. Among other things, she discusses the importance of feminism in her life and her involvement in protests against police brutality in her neighborhood. Her story is a story of trying to help a community empower itself -- and find its own voice. (Summary Written By: Henry Hauser)

title: Local Libraries Memory Circle
description: Participating storytellers include Mary K. Conwell, Estelle Friedman, Felix Morales, Cynthia L. Smith, Becky Koppelman, Bob Isaac, and Tara Kay Johnson

notes: Interviewed by Benjamin de la Piedra

title: Rick van Valkenberg
notes: Interviewed by Benjamin de la Piedra

title: Sandy Jiminez
notes: Interviewed by Benjamin de la Piedra

title: Andrea Arroyo
description: Though born in Mexico, Andrea Arroyo has spent much of her life in New York City, living in several different neighborhoods, including the East Village, the Upper West Side and, most recently, Washington Heights. She is an accomplished artist whose works, dealing primarily with women's issues, have been displayed in many different galleries and in less traditional venues for art, such as Washington Heights' Morris-Jumel Mansion. Andrea discusses some of the things she loves about Washington Heights, including its historical sites, its wide open spaces and parkland, and access to an abundance of fresh produce. (Summary Written By: Henry Hauser)

title: Lynne Van Auken and Bruce Robertson
Broadway Housing Communities - Memory Circle
description: Participating storytellers: Clinton B. Andre, Yvonne Marshall-Andre, Coral Caporale, Cheryl Rogers, Kenne Rogers, Yvonne Simmons, Deborah Plummer, Odessa Starre, Cristina Herrera.

title: NORC El Corazon Memory Circle
description: Participating storytellers: Ofelia Aguilar, Constancia Fennenas, Albania Arias, Bolivia Cascante, Antonia Tita.

title: Isaiah Obie Bing
description: Isaiah Obie Bing discusses his family history and his own experience growing up in New York. Obie´s family were once sharecroppers in South Carolina and Georgia. He describes their odyssey as they first became land owners and later moved to Washington Heights in New York City. Obie talks about growing up in Washington Heights, the games he played, his education and the neighborhood´s tight-knit community. Obie also tells about his career as a mechanical engineer working for Con Edison and his involvement in local community politics. (Summary Written By: Kaitlin McClure)

title: Arlene Schulman
description: Freelance journalist and photographer Arlene Schulman describes how, in the 1980s, her career led her to the upper reaches of Manhattan, to Washington Heights and Inwood, two neighborhoods in transition. At the Westside Gym on 150th Street, she developed her knowledge of boxing. And in Inwood, at the northern tip of Manhattan, she found affordable housing, became involved in community activities and was appointed to the local community board. With an excellent eye for detail, Arlene describes the area's evolution from one with an active drug trade to one that is now attracting young families. She laments the loss of her elderly neighbors, who were once "the eyes and ears of the neighborhood." (Summary Written By: Joanne Dillon)

title: Florence Neumann
description:
Addendum to interview with Florence Neumann
Oral History Project – NYPL – for Inwood-Washington Heights, NY


Notes on Geographic issues in uptown Manhattan:

Postal (later ZIP) codes for northern Manhattan were created and set up in numerical sequence:  10032, 10033 and 10040.

In the early 1960s, four 24-story residential apartment houses were built on the slopes of Ft. George Hill:
	99 Hillside Avenue – opened in 1960 – Inwood Terrace Inc.
	17 Ft. George Hill – opened in 1961 – Inwood Heights Inc.
	11 Ft. George Hill – opened in 1963 – Inwood Tower Inc.
	45 Fairview Avenue – opened in 1963 – Inwood Gardens Inc.

Each house became fully occupied within a short time after opening; waiting lists for apartments were extensive and many families who wished to move into one of these buildings were not able to do so.

At the time that these buildings were occupied, it was determined that the Post Office on Vermilyea Avenue, 10034, would not be able to handle the volume of mail.  Therefore, a new Post Office was created, 10040, and carved out to cover the 4 new buildings, a section of Washington Heights west of Broadway, from ~187th Street to the Hudson River, to the junction of Nagle Avenue, Bennett Avenue and Broadway.  In addition, the ‘triangular’ area bounded by Hillside-Nagle Avenues, Broadway and Dyckman Street was included in the new “Fort George” ZIP Code, 10040.  A new P.O. building was built, also in the red brick used for the four Fort George Inwood properties’ buildings, at the SE corner of Broadway and 196th Street-Hillside Avenue.

Over time, living conditions in Inwood varied, often on a block-by-block basis.  Even on a two-block street, the caliber of the housing stock, overall maintenance of facilities, safety issues, sanitary conditions and street noise, would vary dramatically.

Generally speaking, all areas west of Broadway were more stable and better areas than those east of Broadway.  In particular, the area bounded by 179th Street on the south, Broadway on the east, the Hudson River on the west and Ft. Tryon Park on the north was known to be the safest section in uptown Manhattan and had the least turnover of long-time residents.


Security matters in northern Manhattan –

In the 1980s, as quality of life issues became more pressing and long-time residents’ concerns were less and less addressed due to the increase in serious crime, these developments were noticed by the interviewee:

•	A localized ambulance and emergency care corps was created, called Hatzoloh of Washington Heights and Inwood.  This was based near the leading Orthodox Jewish synagogue on Bennett Avenue, K’hal Adath Jeshurun, at Bennett Avenue and 186th Street.  The EMT corps was NYS certified in emergency care and procedures, with the staff taking refresher courses and passing yearly NYS re-certification tests.  The EMTs and paramedics were/are primarily observant Jewish men in their 20s-40s, all of whom are very committed to saving lives and assisting medically in their immediate area.

•	The ‘street-cop’, a patrolman who walked the streets, knew nearly everyone and was aware of the tone of his ‘beat’, essentially disappeared, with, at the very best, occasional police cars cruising the streets, but rarely stopping.


•	Small grocery stores, “bodegas”, assumed additional functions, becoming the hubs of illicit gambling and drug sales.  This was obvious even to the least aware resident, who could view (especially on Friday nights) parades of cars pulling up in front of a grocery store, certainly not to purchase only chips, sodas or beers.

•	Storefront social clubs were created at venues which previously had been small businesses.  These clubs had opaque-covered up front windows and, it was rumored, admission was restricted to only those who were known to the ‘watchman.’  It was widely assumed that the social clubs were hubs for a steady drug trade.  There were stabbings, shootings and even murders at these clubs.  The social club on my street had several shootings, causing many long-time residents to flee the area and relocate to Riverdale and Queens as quickly as they could find another affordable apartment.  However, as it happened, the owner of this club was then shot and killed – and finally – the place closed down for lack of someone to pay the rent on the facility.

•	According to official police records, the 34th Precinct, which then covered northern Manhattan from 165th Street to the end of the island, had the highest arson, drug and murder rate in Manhattan and was among the top 5 precincts in New York City with the highest levels of serious crimes.

•	This interviewee personally witnessed street fights on our residential street, amongst 100-150 young men, many of them swinging machetes against each other.  Clearly, these were horrifying events which frightened long-time law-abiding residents.

•	Consequently, the stability of the area was severely compromised, causing tenant relocations to safer areas (in NYC, on Long Island, and to New Jersey).  With vacant apartments, many landlords cut-back on maintenance, the delivery of hot water and heat, building repairs, street repairs, painting and plastering apartments, etc.  Apartments were vacant, with occasional squatters.  Landlords began to utilize superintendents (who were untrained in plumbing, plastering, electrical and other repairs) to bring in new tenants whose rents would be heavily subsidized by Federal, State or City housing assistance programs.  Some were “Section 8” tenants; in other cases, 6-8 people (not including infants) lived in an apartment which had previously accommodated 3-5 persons.   

•	The density of the population further exacerbated the living situation, both within the building and especially, in the summer months, when nearly everyone would sit on the pavement, on cars, on fire escapes, etc., so as to try to cool off.  Many people would play radios out loud (all tuned to different stations) and continue throughout the nights since many did not have steady employment and did not need to sleep so as to hold down a job.


Medical Services in northern Manhattan in the 1950s and 1960s.

In the post WWII area, health insurance was a luxury.  My own parents, who emigrated to the USA after the War, and had been fortunate enough to spend the war years in Great Britain, were aghast to discover that in the USA, there was no national health insurance.  My mother often remarked that even as ‘a bloody refugee’ in England, she knew that she could receive medical care if necessary.  

In our own family, my father struggled to earn a modest income.  There were no luxuries and we did with very little.  My sister and I usually wore ‘hand-me-down’ clothing, received from older girls who lived in our building, baby-sitters or older relatives.

I mention this only to highlight the urgency and sacrifices which were made by my parents so that our family would have, at least, what was called “Major Medical” coverage – for hospitalization and out-patient surgery.  The premiums were paid by our family; this coverage was not included in any so-called job benefits.  It was quite difficult - - 

In terms of primary medical care, many doctors in our area converted residential apartments to offices.  In our own building, in Apt. A6 on the main floor, right off the lobby, Dr. Fox practiced (she was a lady.)  She and her husband (a teacher) lived in a 5-room apartment:  the hallway and another room were converted to a waiting room and storage facility; another room was converted to an examination room; there may have been a smaller room converted to a lab or x-ray developing room and/or medical supply storage room.  Patients paid cash unless they had medical coverage through a union plan.  It was comforting to have a doctor so near our apartment, even though Dr. Fox was not our family doctor.

The Neumann family went to Dr. Frederic Grossman, who maintained offices nearby, at 20 Sherman Avenue.  Dr. Grossman’s wife, Friedel, was a registered nurse who assisted him greatly.  Dr. Grossman’s practice consisted of his office, containing an examination table; the nurse’s room, containing a bed/stretcher sometimes used for ‘sunlight-electric light’ treatments for frail children, and a waiting room, always filled with at least 20-30 people waiting to see the doctor.  I remember there was a refrigerator in the corner of the waiting room, filled with bottles of Ginger Ale.  Dr. Grossman would stop into the waiting room, say hello to those assembled there, and take a big cup of Ginger Ale prior to seeing the next patient.  

Patients were seen on a first-come, first served basis, unless there was a dire emergency.  Payments were in cash; the doctor charged very little to each patient.

If someone was very sick, as I was when I had Measles, Chicken Pox and German Measles, Dr. Grossman would make a house visit and provide treatment.  He always came when he said he would come, even if he was running late.

There were other doctors in our immediate area.  Among them were Dr. Fox, (previously mentioned); Dr. Samuel Gelmann (his office was in 2 Thayer Street, later he relocated to Riverside Drive); and Drs. Ludwig Wolfermann, a medical doctor and his wife, Dr. Joan Wolfermann, a practicing dentist, on Riverside Drive.  Dr. Franklin Ward, a well-known and beloved doctor, maintained his office on 204th Street near Seaman Avenue.  (After Dr. Grossman retired, the Neumanns often went to Dr. Ward for medical assistance.)  I believe there were other physicians in the immediate area.

Many doctors in our area were Jewish doctors who needed ‘admitting rights’ for their patients to a local hospital.  In those days, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital was known to have a discriminatory policy against Jewish doctors.  Consequently, the doctors I mentioned above, and others, brought their patients to smaller, less known and now defunct hospitals.  These included:
•	Gotham Hospital (located then on 76th Street at Fifth Avenue)
•	Wadsworth Hospital (formerly on 185th Street near Wadsworth Avenue); 
•	St. Elizabeth Hospital (a small Catholic hospital on Ft. Washington Avenue at 190th Street – now converted to luxury residential condominiums) and 
•	Jewish Memorial Hospital, at 4600 Broadway at ~196th Street.  (This location is now Intermediate School 218 – the Salome Urena de Henrique School.)

In terms of protecting children against polio, the Salk vaccine was the only vaccine available in the 1950s.  All children, including those who attended private and/or parochial schools, were vaccinated.  I received four injections – all were administered at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital on 168th Street.  We were taken class by class.  We all had to line up, it was done rather quickly, and we received a lollypop (although I recall that I received a lollypop that was not the color I had requested.)  

We were the lucky kids:  I recall that a girl on my block, who was probably not more than 2-3 years old than I was, was stricken with polio.  While later in life, she was able to walk, she always needed two canes or a walker to get around.  She married, held down a job and bore two children.  She seems to have raised them by herself (her husband was known to be a drunk and was rarely seen with the children.)  She worked until she must have been in her early 60s, living all the time in the same house where she grew up.  I heard that she has now retired and that her daughter, who lives ‘upstate’, asked her mother to come and live with her.

I recall that when I was in (Yeshiva Soloveichik’s) elementary school, there was great debate about supplying children in parochial schools with milk containers.  The argument against this was the division of state and church:  it was said that children who attended religious schools should provide on their own for milk cartons.  The counter argument, which finally prevailed, was that the health and nutrition of children should not be dependent on the type of education they received.  All children should be supplied with a small container of milk for lunch.  Thankfully, this view prevailed and we, in religious day schools, were able to receive our milk.


Submitted by:
Florence Neumann
June 18, 2015

title: Harlan Pruden
description: Harlan is an activist and advocate for change in Inwood. He speaks about the virgin forest of Inwood Hills Park, being a community board member of Community District 12, community and business development, real estate, Manhattan's pre-colonization, architecture, his Native American ancestry, and the LGBT community. (Summary Written By: Sherri Niziolek)

title: Ed Lehner
description: Ed Lehner discusses growing up in Washington Heights Inwood. He talks about the changing face of the neighborhood: the different communities that have come and gone, the local shops that have managed to hang on and those that have closed their doors. He talks about his favorite sports teams, the games he played growing up and his stamp and baseball card collections. Ed also talks about how politics helped him become the outgoing individual he is today and the high points in his career, such as his involvement with the famous Pooper Scooper Law. (Summary Written By: Kaitlin McClure)

title: Mario Tavarez
description: Mario Tavarez moved to Inwood in 1970 and still lives there. His involvement with the community has been through his two passions: baseball and art. His decades-long involvement with the neighborhood’s little league has spawned lasting relationships with young players he has encountered, including Pittsburgh Pirates third baseman Pedro Alvarez. Art has long played a major role in Mario’s life. Some of his paintings now hang in the Columbia University Medical Center and the Inwood branch of the New York Public Library. Although he has seen great changes in Inwood, some of which he laments, Mario is proud of the neighborhood, praising community initiatives to connect people with their roots. He is even able to rattle off an exhaustive list of Inwood’s most famous residents. (Summary Written By: Henry Hauser)

title: Led Black
description: Led Black tells his story of growing up in Washington Heights. He talks about his mother's emigration from the Dominican Republic and his early life moving back to the United States after having lived in the Dominican Republic for several years. Led discusses his education, how he discovered his love of history and what it was like to experience the changes that occurred in Washington Heights. He mentions his favorite Washington Heights haunts and how the neighborhood is different from when he was younger. He also discusses his part in the Uptown Renaissance and the local neighborhood politics. (Summary Written By: Kaitlin McClure)

title: Jeanlee Poggi
description: Jeanlee Poggi describes growing up in a small town in Iowa and how she ended up in New York City. She talks about her first and second marriages and the trajectory her career took after college. Her love of literature and people drew her to teaching. That same love drew her into the community projects in Washington Heights that she has been so involved with. Along with other community volunteers, Jeanlee began transforming empty lots into welcoming community spaces, and their hard work has ultimately resulted in the creation of the West 181st Street Beautification Project. (Summary Written By: Kaitlin McClure)

title: Memory Circle - Latino Americans on October 8th
description: Participating Storytellers: Rene De Los Santos, Clara Galvano, Mario Tavarez, Alicia Gonzalez

title: Food Memory Circle
description: Regina Gradess and Bob Isaac participated in this Memory Circle about food in Washington Heights and Inwood.

title: Mark Levine
description: Councilman Mark Levine speaks about being a teacher in Washington Heights, the non-profit he started for low-income, immigrant families, the credit union he started, how he and his family used the public library growing up, his representation of the 7th Council District, the tenant's rights he's working on (mainly for the right to have counsel in housing court), how the multi-cultural community has impacted his life and shaped his personal and political identity, the Jewish Community, and local establishments both gone and new. (Summary Written By: Sherri Niziolek)
